bioghist.p: John S. Hilles was the son of Samuel Hilles (1788-1873) and Margaret Hill Smith (1786-1881). He attended Haverford in 1844, leaving in 1845 because of the temporary closing of the school. He was in the shipping business in Philadelphia. In 1862 he married Sarah Cooper Tatum (1832-1914). His brother, William Smith Hilles (1825-1876), attended Haverford in the first class of students in 1833. He left the college and returned as a member of the class of 1840. He worked in manufacturing and banking. Sarah's brother was John Cooper Tatum. He attended Haverford from 1850 to 1852. He was a farmer and the Director of the First National Bank in Woodbury, New Jersey. Their parents were Joseph Tatum and Anne Cooper Tatum.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers of the Hilles family from the 1820s to the 1870s. Materials include: correspondence; Hilles family deeds and property transactions; documents relating to John S. Hilles's work with freed slaves during the Civil War; a small batch of deeds, stock records and military passes of John S. Hilles; and Haverford school records of W.S. Hilles. Much of the correspondence is addressed to Sarah Tatum Hilles and dates from both before and after her marriage to John Hilles. Other correspondents include Mary Tatum Whitall, Joseph Tatum, John Cooper Tatum, and John Hilles. Also included in the collection are cassette and reel to reel tapes of The Religious Philosophy of History by Howard H. Brinton and a series of his lectures.
